Beside the royal palace is the Buddha's Tooth Relic Temple, adorned with various treasures, its radiance dazzling, passed down through generations, revered without decline.

The present king, Alakaketu, a native of Kalinga, worships non-Buddhist teachings and does not respect Buddhism. He is violent, cruel, and does not care for the people of the country, despising the Buddha's tooth relic.
In the third year of the Yongle era of the great Ming dynasty, the emperor sent the eunuch Zheng He as an envoy to offer incense and flowers to the country to make offerings.
Zheng He advised King Alakaketu to respect Buddhism and stay away from non-Buddhist teachings.
The king became angry and wanted to harm him. Zheng He knew of the plot and left.

Later, Zheng He was again sent to bestow gifts on various barbarians. He bestowed gifts on the king of Sri Lanka, but the king became even more arrogant and disrespectful, wanting to plot against the envoy.
He used 50,000 soldiers to block the road with wood, and divided his troops to rob the sea-going ships.
He leaked the plan in advance to those under him.
Zheng He and the others realized it and quickly returned to the ship. The road was already blocked, so they secretly sent someone out. The ship's crew refused them.
Zheng He, with 3,000 soldiers, secretly attacked and entered the king's city by a detour at night and guarded it.
The barbarian soldiers who had robbed the sea-going ships, together with the barbarian soldiers within the country, attacked from all sides, encircling them several times.

They fought for six days. Zheng He and the others captured their king. At dawn, they opened the gate, cut down trees to make a path, and fought their way for more than 20 li. They reached the ship at dusk.

They were about to request to pay homage to the Buddha's tooth relic. It was extraordinary and radiant, just as described before. There were loud thunderclaps that startled those who saw it from afar.

He traveled through the vast ocean for hundreds of thousands of miles, and the wind and waves did not frighten him, as if walking on level ground. Fierce dragons and evil fish appeared in front of him, but he calmly did not harm them.
The people in the boat were all safe and happy.
On the ninth day of the seventh month in the ninth year of the Yongle era, he arrived in the capital.
The emperor ordered that it be enshrined in the imperial city, in a sandalwood and diamond jeweled seat, and made offerings to it.
He benefited sentient beings and prayed for blessings for the people, creating immeasurable merit and virtue.
